thread.title: Gwinnett clinic closes, others expand or open
thread.title_full: Gwinnett clinic closes, others expand or open | www.ajc.com

author: Arielle Kass
title: Gwinnett clinic closes, others expand or open
text:
The Gwinnett Community Clinic, a Snellville non-profit for those without health insurance, will close its doors Thursday.
At the same time, leaders at two other clinics say they are taking care of more patients because of a rising need for health care.
The Good Samaritan Health Center of Gwinnett is moving and expanding. And a retired doctor is opening Bridge Atlanta Medical Center in Norcross.
Medical assistant Mary Banks prepares the syringes Tuesday to be dispersed about 6 kiosks. The AeroClinic began administering seasonal flu shots to the traveling public Tuesday, September 15, 2009 at Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport in Atlanta. 6 kiosks in A, B, and C concourses along with 2 of their clinics located on the third floor atrium level and near the security checkpoint will administer the vaccine for $ 35.00 Monday through Friday 7AM-7PM, Saturday, 8AM - 4PM and Sunday, 11AM - 7PM. This is the fourth year The AeroClinic has provided the shots and will also be doing them in Charlotte and Philadelphiaâ€™s airports. Some other airports across the country also provide the service under different providers. The AeroClinic will also be registering with the state to provide the H1N1 vaccine when it becomes reportedly available sometime in October. The shots will be available all through the flu season until late December and may extend into January if the CDC deems it necessary. The AeroClinic has hired an additional 20 people to man the kiosks that also include privacy screens. Normally The AeroClinic provides medical care at the airport 365 days a year for the traveling public in Atlanta. John Spink, jspink@ajc.com To read more about health care in the county, click here .
